results.headline: Why, Oh Why, Oh Why, Oh, Send Us to Wy-o-ming?
results.display_title: Did You Hear About the Morgans?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Did You Hear About the Morgans?

results.summary_short: There are barely enough titter-worthy one-liners in “Did You Hear About the Morgans?” to prevent it from sinking under the weight of its clichés.

results.headline: Building a New World and Populating It With Plastic

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Town Called Panic

results.summary_short: “A Town Called Panic” is an adventure story as fast-paced and exciting as any currently in theaters.

results.headline: A Country Crooner Whose Flight Is Now Free Fall

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Crazy Heart

results.summary_short: “Crazy Heart,” written and directed by Scott Cooper, is a small movie perfectly scaled to the big performance at its center.

results.headline: Imagine Childproofing for a Winged Baby

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ricky

results.summary_short: As François Ozon’s “Ricky” rubs its genres together, it creates a sense of discomfort.

results.headline: High Road in Business? He Takes It
results.display_title: Rocket Singh - Salesman of the Year

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rocket Singh - Salesman of the Year

results.summary_short: Ranbir Kapoor turns in a skillfully understated performance in “Rocket Singh: Salesman of the Year.”

results.headline: Final Score: Future 1, Past 0

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Invictus

results.summary_short: Clint Eastwood’s “Invictus,” a rousing true story of athletic triumph, is also that director’s latest exploration of revenge, the defining theme of his career.

results.headline: The Young and the Not So Innocent, Swooning Over a Homicidal Fella

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tenderness

results.summary_short: “Tenderness” is an odd, frustrating hybrid of serial-killer suspense film and moody character study of disturbed teenagers.

results.headline: A Restaurant in Full Hustle on a Make-or-Break Night

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Slammin' Salmon

results.summary_short: “The Slammin’ Salmon” takes the premise of “Big Night,” one of the most sublime restaurant movies ever made, and tries to adapt it for the gross-out set.

results.headline: A Love That Speaks Its Name: A College Professor’s Fateful Day

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Single Man

results.summary_short: Colin Firth wears the face of grief in Tom Ford’s directorial debut, “A Single Man.”

results.headline: A Saber for Mother, and Ostriches for All
results.display_title: My Son, My Son, What Have Ye Done

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Son, My Son, What Have Ye Done

results.summary_short: While watching Werner Herzog’s “My Son, My Son, What Have Ye Done” you might be tempted to murmur, “My Werner, My Werner, What Have Ye Done.”

results.headline: Gazing Down, From a Suburb of Heaven, at an Earthly Purgatory

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Lovely Bones

results.summary_short: A victim obsessed with the lives that go on without her is at the center of “The Lovely Bones.”

results.headline: Even at Death’s Door, a Lesbian Couple Still Find Peace Elusive

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hannah Free

results.summary_short: “Hannah Free” is a tear-jerker about longtime lesbian lovers languishing in the same Michigan nursing home.

results.headline: Subsisting on Cellphones and Hope

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sincerely Yours

results.summary_short: “Sincerely Yours” conveys a mood of urban desolation in an impersonal universe.

results.headline: Digging Up All the Old Vampire Jokes

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Transylmania

results.summary_short: “Transylmania,” a vampire-hunter, college road trip sex comedy, has a problem: someone has drained all the laughs out of it.

results.headline: Truck Heist Hits a Skid in a B Movie With a Soul

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Armored

results.summary_short: “Armored,” an unpretentious action thriller about a supposedly bloodless robbery that turns foul and messy, is basic, brutal and sometimes clumsy, but far from dumb.

results.headline: Neither Here Nor There

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Up in the Air

results.summary_short: One of the pleasures of “Up in the Air” is that its actresses share the frame with George Clooney as equals, not props.

results.headline: The Music of Church Burning

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Until the Light Takes Us

results.summary_short: “Until the Light Takes Us” recounts how a few Norwegian musicians hijacked an obscure offshoot of heavy metal.

results.headline: Swimming With Crocodiles, but Well Oiled

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Big River Man

results.summary_short: With “Big River Man,” the director John Maringouin has shaped a richly textured narrative about human endeavor.

results.headline: A Devoted Worker in a Dead-End Job

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Strip

results.summary_short: “The Strip” sweats to wring laughs from overworked themes and underwhelming performances.

results.headline: Following the Master to the End of the Line

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Last Station

results.summary_short: To say that the actors in “The Last Station” overdo it would be an understatement.
